question: Question 1 Let [latex]C[/latex] be a clockwise oriented closed curve in the complex plane defined by [latex]|z|=1[/latex]. Further, let [latex]f(z)=j z[/latex] be a complex function, where [latex]j=\sqrt{-1}[/latex]. Then, [latex]\oint_{{C}} {f}({z}) {dz}=[/latex] ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Step 1: Express the function We are given [latex] f(z) = jz [/latex], and we want to compute: [latex] \oint_C jz , dz [/latex] Step 2: Use properties of contour integrals [latex] j = \sqrt{-1} [/latex] is a constant, so it can be pulled out of the integral: [latex] \oint_C jz , dz = j \oint_C z , dz [/latex] Step 3: Recall the standard result For a closed contour [latex] C [/latex] enclosing the origin (like [latex] |z| = 1 [/latex]), [latex] \oint_C z , dz = 0 [/latex] because [latex] z [/latex] is an analytic function inside and on [latex] C [/latex]. Step 4: Apply the result [latex] \oint_C f(z) , dz = j \cdot 0 = 0 [/latex]

question: Question 2 Consider ordinary differential equations given by [latex]\dot{x}_{1}({t})=2 {x}_{2}({t}) [/latex] [latex] \dot{{x}}_{2}({t})={r}({t})[/latex] with initial conditions [latex]{x}_{1}(0)=1[/latex] and [latex]{x}_{2}(0)=0[/latex]. If [latex]r(t)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}1, & t \geq 0 \\ 0, & t < 0\end{array}\right.[/latex], then at [latex]t=1, x_{1}(t)=[/latex] ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Given [latex]\frac{{dx}_{1}}{{dt}}=2 {x}_{2} \quad ...(1)[/latex] [latex]\frac{{dx}_{2}}{{dt}}={r}({t}), \quad {r}({t})=\left\{\begin{array}{l}1: {t} \geq 0 \\ 0: {t} < 0 \end{array}\right.[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{{dx}_{2}}{{dt}}=1[/latex] for [latex]{t} \geq 0 \quad ...(2)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow {x}_{2}={t}+{c}  \quad ...(3)[/latex] Given [latex]x_{2}(0)=0[/latex] (3) [latex]\Rightarrow 0=0+c \Rightarrow c=0[/latex] [latex]\therefore {x}_{2}={t}[/latex] From (1) [latex]\frac{d x_{1}}{d t}=2 t[/latex] [latex]
\Rightarrow {x}_{1}=\frac{2 {t}^{2}}{2}+{K} \quad ...(4)
[/latex] Given [latex]{x}_{1}(0)=1:(4) \Rightarrow 1=0+{K}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow {K}=1[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] From (4) [latex]{x}_{1}={t}^{2}+1[/latex] Now [latex]{X}_{1}(1)=1+1=2[/latex]

question: Question 3 Let [latex](\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}) \in \mathfrak{R}^{2}[/latex]. solution:
Step 1: Direction vector and its unit vector The direction vector from origin to point (1, 2) is: [latex] \vec{u} = \langle 1, 2 angle [/latex] Magnitude of this vector is: [latex] |\vec{u}| = \sqrt{1^2 + 2^2} = \sqrt{5} [/latex] Unit vector in the given direction is: [latex] \hat{u} = \left\langle  rac{1}{\sqrt{5}},  rac{2}{\sqrt{5}} ightangle [/latex] Step 2: Compute the gradient of V(x, y) [latex] 
abla V = \left\langle  rac{\partial V}{\partial x},  rac{\partial V}{\partial y} ightangle = \left\langle 2x + 1, 2y ightangle [/latex] At the origin (0, 0), the gradient becomes: [latex] 
abla V(0, 0) = \langle 1, 0 angle [/latex] Step 3: Compute the directional derivative Directional derivative of V in the direction of unit vector [latex] \hat{u} [/latex] is: [latex] D_{\hat{u}} V = 
abla V \cdot \hat{u} = \langle 1, 0 angle \cdot \left\langle  rac{1}{\sqrt{5}},  rac{2}{\sqrt{5}} ightangle =  rac{1}{\sqrt{5}} [/latex] Numerical value: [latex]  rac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \approx  rac{1}{2.236} \approx 0.447 [/latex]

Step 1: Given: [latex] Y = X^2 [/latex], and [latex] X \in (0, 1] [/latex] with uniform distribution: [latex] P_X(x) = 1 [/latex] for [latex] x \in (0, 1] [/latex] Step 2: Use the change of variable technique for continuous random variables. If [latex] Y = g(X) = X^2 [/latex], then [latex] X = \sqrt{Y} [/latex] (since [latex] X > 0 [/latex]), and the PDF of [latex] Y [/latex] is: [latex] P_Y(y) = P_X(x) \cdot \left| \frac{dx}{dy} \right| [/latex] We know [latex] x = \sqrt{y} [/latex], so: [latex] \frac{dx}{dy} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} [/latex] Therefore: [latex] P_Y(y) = P_X(\sqrt{y}) \cdot \left| \frac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} \right| = 1 \cdot \frac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} [/latex], for [latex] y \in (0, 1] [/latex] Step 3: So the correct PDF of [latex] Y [/latex] is: [latex] P_Y(y) = \begin{cases} \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{y}}, & y \in (0, 1] \ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} [/latex] Final Answer: (A) [latex] \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{y}} [/latex], for [latex] y \in (0, 1] [/latex]

question: Question 5 Consider discrete random variables X and Y with probabilities as follows: [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{X}=0[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Y}=0)=\frac{1}{4}[/latex], [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{X}=1[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Y}=0)=\frac{1}{8}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{X}=0[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Y}=1)=\frac{1}{2}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{X}=1[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Y}=1)=\frac{1}{8}[/latex] Given [latex]\mathrm{X}=1[/latex], the expected value of [latex]\mathrm{Y}[/latex] is
solution: Step 1: Identify the conditional probabilities of [latex] Y [/latex] given [latex] X = 1 [/latex]. From the given: [latex] P(X=1, Y=0) = \frac{1}{8}, \quad P(X=1, Y=1) = \frac{1}{8} [/latex] So, total probability [latex] P(X=1) = \frac{1}{8} + \frac{1}{8} = \frac{1}{4} [/latex] Step 2: Compute the conditional probabilities: [latex] P(Y=0 \mid X=1) = \frac{P(X=1, Y=0)}{P(X=1)} = \frac{\frac{1}{8}}{\frac{1}{4}} = \frac{1}{2} [/latex] [latex] P(Y=1 \mid X=1) = \frac{P(X=1, Y=1)}{P(X=1)} = \frac{\frac{1}{8}}{\frac{1}{4}} = \frac{1}{2} [/latex] Step 3: Compute the expected value: [latex] \mathbb{E}[Y \mid X=1] = 0 \cdot P(Y=0 \mid X=1) + 1 \cdot P(Y=1 \mid X=1) = 0 \cdot \frac{1}{2} + 1 \cdot \frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{2} [/latex] Final Answer: (B) [latex] \frac{1}{2} [/latex]

Question 7 Let [latex]\mathrm{A}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 1 & 1 \\ -1 & -1 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & -1\end{array}\right][/latex], and [latex]\mathrm{b}=\left[\begin{array}{c}1 / 3 \\  -1 / 3 \\ 0\end{array}\right][/latex]. Then, the system of linear equations [latex]\mathrm{Ax}=\mathrm{b}[/latex] has
solution: [latex](A \mid B)=\left[\begin{array}{lll|c}1 & 1 & 1 & 1 / 3 \\ -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 / 3\\ 0 & 1 & -1 & 0\end{array}\right][/latex] [latex]\mathrm{R}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{R}_{2}+\mathrm{R}_{1}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow(\mathrm{A} \mid \mathrm{B}) \sim\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}1 & 1 & 1 & 1 / 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & -1 & 0\end{array}\right][/latex] [latex]\mathrm{R}_{2} \leftrightarrows \mathrm{R}_{3}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow(\mathrm{A} \mid \mathrm{B}) \sim\left[\begin{array}{lll|c}1 & 1 & 1 & 1 / 3 \\ 0 & 1 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0\end{array}\right][/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \rho(\mathrm{A})=2=\rho(\mathrm{A} \mid \mathrm{B}) < \mathrm{n}=3[/latex] (no. of variables) [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{Ax}=\mathrm{b}[/latex] will have an infinite no. of solutions

question: Question 8 Let [latex]v_{1}[/latex] and [latex]v_{2}[/latex] be the two eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues of a [latex]3 \times 3[/latex] real symmetric matrix. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: Step 1: Given that the matrix is a real symmetric matrix. Step 2: A well-known property of real symmetric matrices is that eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues are orthogonal. Step 3: If [latex] \mathbf{v}_1 [/latex] and [latex] \mathbf{v}_2 [/latex] are eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues of a real symmetric matrix, then: [latex] \mathbf{v}_1^T \mathbf{v}_2 = 0 [/latex] This means they are orthogonal. Step 4: Among the given options, option (B) matches this condition. Final Answer: (B) [latex] \mathbf{v}_1^T \mathbf{v}_2 = 0 [/latex]

question: Question 9 Consider the set [latex]S[/latex] of points [latex](x, y) \in  \mathfrak{R}^2[/latex] which minimize the real-valued function [latex]f(x, y) = (x + y - 1)^2 + (x + y)^2[/latex] Which of the following statements is true about the set [latex]S[/latex]?
solution: We are given: [latex]f(x, y) = (x + y - 1)^2 + (x + y)^2[/latex] Step 1: Substitute a single variable Let [latex]u = x + y[/latex] Then, the function becomes: [latex]f(x, y) = (u - 1)^2 + u^2 = u^2 - 2u + 1 + u^2 = 2u^2 - 2u + 1[/latex] Step 2: Minimize [latex]f(u) = 2u^2 - 2u + 1[/latex] This is a quadratic function in [latex]u[/latex] with a positive coefficient, so it has a unique minimum. The minimum occurs at: [latex]u = \frac{-(-2)}{2 \cdot 2} = \frac{2}{4} = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] So, the function is minimized when [latex]x + y = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] Step 3: Analyze the set [latex]S[/latex] All points [latex](x, y)[/latex] satisfying [latex]x + y = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] will minimize [latex]f(x, y)[/latex]. There are infinitely many such points in [latex]\mathbb{R}^2[/latex]. Final Answer: [latex]\boxed{\text{The number of elements in the set } S \text{ is infinite}}[/latex] Correct Option: (B)

options.A: The number of elements in the set S is finite and more than one.
options.B: The number of elements in the set S is infinite.
options.D: The number of elements in the set S is exactly one.

question: Question 13 Consider a vector [latex] \bar{u}=2 \hat{x}+\hat{y}+2 \hat{z} [/latex], where [latex] \hat{x}, \hat{y}, \hat{z} [/latex] represent unit vector along the coordinate axes [latex] x, y, z [/latex] respectively. The directional derivative of the function [latex] f(x, y, z)=2 \ln (x y)+\ln (y z)+3 \ln (x z) [/latex] at the point [latex] (x, y, z)=(1,1,1) [/latex] in the direction of [latex] \bar{u} [/latex] is
solution:
We know that: directional derivative of '[latex] f [/latex]' at [latex] P(1,1,1) [/latex] in the direction of [latex] \vec{a} [/latex] is given by [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\text { Directional derivative } & =\nabla f \cdot \frac{\hat{a}}{|\bar{a}|} \\
\nabla f & =\hat{i} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}+\hat{j} \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}+\hat{k} \frac{\partial f}{\partial z} \\
\nabla f & =i \frac{5}{x}+j \frac{3}{y}+k \frac{4}{z} \\
(\nabla f)_{(1,1,1)} & =5 i+3 j+4 k
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Directional derivative [latex] =\overline{\nabla f} \cdot \frac{\bar{a}}{|\bar{a}|}=(5 i+3 j+4 k) \cdot \frac{(2 i+j+2 k)}{\sqrt{2^{2}+1^{2}+2^{2}}}=\frac{21}{3}=7 [/latex]

Question 20 The closed curve shown in the figure is described by [latex]r=1+\cos \theta[/latex], where [latex]r=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}[/latex]
 [latex]x=r \cos \theta, y=r \sin \theta[/latex] The magnitude of the line integral of the vector field [latex]F=-y \hat{i}+x \hat{j}[/latex] around the closed curve is ___(Round off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
I & =\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \vec{F} \cdot \overrightarrow{d l} \\
& =\int_{0}^{2 \pi}(-y \hat{i}+x)(d x \hat{i}+d y) \\
& =\int_{0}^{2 \pi}(-y d x+x d y)
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Given : [latex]\quad x=r \cos \theta[/latex] and [latex]y=r \sin \theta[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\therefore I&=\int_{0}^{2 \pi}[(-r \sin \theta)(-r \sin \theta) d \theta+(r \cos \theta)(r \cos \theta) d \theta] \\
&=\int_{0}^{2 \pi} r^{2} d \theta \\
&=\int_{0}^{2 \pi}(1+\cos \theta)^{2} d \theta \\
&=\int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left(1+\cos ^{2} \theta+2 \cos \theta\right) d \theta \\
&=\int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left(1+\frac{1+\cos 2 \theta}{2}+2 \cos \theta\right) \mathrm{d} \theta \\
&=3 \pi=9.425
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 23 Three points in the [latex]x-y[/latex] plane are [latex](-1,0.8)[/latex] [latex](0,2.2)[/latex] and [latex](1,2.8)[/latex]. The value of the slope of the best fit straight line in the least square sense is ___  (Round off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Straight line equation, [latex]y=a x+b[/latex] [Let] where, [latex]a=[/latex] slope By lest approximation, [latex]
\sum \mathrm{y}_{i}=a \sum \mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{i}}+\mathrm{bn}

\hline

\hline
\end{array}
[/latex] From eqn. (1), we get [latex]

Question 28 Let the probability density function of a random variable [latex]x [/latex] be given as [latex]f(x)=ae^{-2|x|} [/latex] The value of [latex] 'a'[/latex] is _________
solution:
[latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix}
ae^{2x} &x \lt 0 \\ 
 ae^{-2x} &x \gt 0 
\end{matrix}\right. [/latex] Therefore, [latex] \begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }f(x)dx&=1\\
\int_{-\infty }^{0}ae^{2x}dx+\int_{0 }^{\infty }ae^{-2x}dx&=1\\
a\left [ \left [ \frac{e^{2x}}{2} \right ]_{-\infty }^0 +[ \left [ \frac{e^{-2x}}{-2} \right ]^{\infty }_0\right ]&=1\\
a\left [ \frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2} \right ]&=1\\
a&=1
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 29 Let [latex] \vec{E}(x,y,z)=2x^2\hat{i}+5y\hat{j}+3z\hat{k}[/latex]. The value of [latex] \int \int \int _V(\vec{\triangledown }\cdot \vec{E})dV[/latex], where [latex] V[/latex] is the

solution: Divergence of [latex]\vec{V}, \triangledown \cdot \vec{V}=4x+5+3=4x+8 [/latex] Now, [latex]\int \int \int( \triangledown \cdot \vec{V})dxdydz=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{0}^{1}\int_{0}^{1}(4x+8)dxdydz=\int_{0}^{1}(4x+8)dx=[2x^2+8x]_0^1=10 [/latex]

question:
Question 30 Let [latex] R[/latex] be a region in the first quadrant of the [latex] xy[/latex] plane enclosed by a closed curve [latex] C[/latex]
considered in counter-clockwise direction. Which of the following expressions does
not represent the area of the region [latex] R[/latex]?
solution:
Using green theorem?s [latex] \oint _cF_1dx+F_2dy=\int \int _R\left ( \frac{\partial F_2}{\partial x} -\frac{\partial F_1}{\partial y}\right )dxdy [/latex] Check all the options: [latex] \oint xdy=\int \int _R\left ( \frac{\partial x}{\partial x} -0\right )dxdy=\int \int _Rdxdy[/latex] [latex] \frac{1}{2}\oint xdy-ydx=\frac{1}{2}\int \int _R(1+1)dxdy=\int \int _Rdxdy [/latex] [latex] \oint ydx=\int \int _R(-1)dxdy=-\int \int _Rdxdy [/latex] Hence, 
[latex]\oint ydx [/latex] is not represent the area of the
region.

question: Question 31 Let, [latex] f(x,y,z)=4x^2+7xy+3xz^2[/latex]. The direction in which the function [latex]f(x,y,z)[/latex] increases most rapidly at point [latex] P = (1,0,2)[/latex] is

Given:
[latex]f(x,y,z)=4x^2+7xy+3xz^2 [/latex] The directional derivative at point P is given by [latex]=\triangledown f|_{point \; P} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \; \triangledown f=(8x+7y+3z^2)\hat{i}+(0+7x+0)\hat{j}+(0+0+6xz)\hat{k}[/latex] at point (1, 0, 2) [latex]\triangledown f|_{(1,0,2)}=20\hat{i}+7\hat{j}+12\hat{k} [/latex]

question: Question 35 Consider a 3 x 3 matrix A whose (i,j)-th element, [latex]a_{i,j}=(i-j)^3[/latex]. Then the matrix A will be
solution: [latex] for \; i=j\Rightarrow a_{ij}=(i-i)^3=0\forall i[/latex] [latex] for \; i\neq j\Rightarrow a_{ij}=(i-j)^3=(-(j-i))^3=-(j-i)^3=-a_{ji}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \; A_{3 \times 3 }[/latex]  is skew symmetric matrix.

question: Question 36 Let A be a [latex]10\times10[/latex] matrix such that [latex]A^{5}[/latex] is a null matrix, and let I be the [latex]10\times10[/latex] identity matrix. The determinant of [latex]\text{A+I}[/latex] is ___________________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given}:\qquad A^{5}&=0\\ A x &=\lambda x \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad A^{5} x &=\lambda^{5} x \quad(\because x \neq 0) \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \lambda^{5} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \lambda &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Eigen values of [latex]A+I[/latex] given [latex]\lambda+1[/latex] [latex] \because [/latex] Eigen values of [latex]I_{A}=1[/latex] Hence [latex]|A+I|=[/latex] Product of eigen values [latex]=1 \times 1 \times 1 \times \ldots 10 [/latex]times [latex] =1[/latex]

question:
Question 37 Let [latex]\left ( -1 -j \right ), \left ( 3 -j \right ), \left ( 3 + j \right )[/latex]
 and [latex]\left ( -1+ j \right )[/latex] be the vertices of a rectangle C in the complex plane. Assuming that C is traversed in counter-clockwise direction, the value of the contour integral [latex]\oint _{C}\dfrac{dz}{z^{2}\left ( z-4 \right )}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\oint_{C} \frac{d z}{z^{2}(z-4)}[/latex] Singularities are given by [latex]z^{2}(z-4)=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad z=0,4[/latex] [latex] z=0[/latex] is pole of order [latex]m=2[/latex] lies inside contour 'c' [latex] z=4[/latex] is pole of order [latex]m=1[/latex] lies outside 'c' [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Res}_{0} &=\frac{1}{(2-1) !} \text{lt}_{\rightarrow 0} \frac{d^{2-1}}{d z^{2-1}}\left[(z-0)^{2} \frac{1}{z^{2}(z-4)}\right] \\ &=\frac{-1}{(0.4)^{2}}=\frac{-1}{16}\\ \text{By CRT}\\ \oint_{C} f(z) d z &=2 \pi j \text{Res}_{0}=2 \pi j\left[\frac{-1}{16}\right] \\ &=\frac{-j \pi }{8} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 38 Suppose the probability that a coin toss shows "head" is p, where [latex]0\lt 
 p\lt 1[/latex]. The coin is tossed repeatedly until the first "head" appears. The expected number of tosses required is
solution: [latex]F(H) = p[/latex], let x = Number of tosses [latex] \begin{aligned} &\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline x & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 \ldots \\ \hline P(x) & p & (1-p) p & (1-p)^{2} p & & \\ \hline \end{array}\\ &\begin{aligned} E(x) &=\sum x_{i} P(x)=p+2(1-p) p+3(p)(1-p)^{2}+\ldots \\ &=p\left[1+2(1-p)+3(1-p)^{2}+\ldots\right] \\ &=p[1-(1-p)]^{-2}=\frac{1}{p} \end{aligned} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 In the open interval [latex]\left ( 0,1 \right )[/latex], the polynomial [latex]p\left ( x \right) =x^{4}-4x^{3}+2[/latex] has
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x^{4}+2 &=4 x^{3} \\ f_{1}(x) &=x^{4}+2 \\ f_{2}(x) &=4 x^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] It is clear that point of intersection of these graphs is solution (or) root of [latex]p(x) = 0[/latex] According to intermediate value theorem [latex] P(0)[/latex] and [latex]P(1)[/latex] are having opposite signs [latex] \therefore [/latex] a root of [latex]p(x) = 0[/latex] in [latex](0, 1)[/latex] and also from graph, there is only one point of intersection Hence exactly one real root exists in [latex](0, 1)[/latex]

question: Question 40 Suppose the circles [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}=1[/latex] and [latex]\left ( x-1\right )^{2}+\left ( y-1 \right )^{2}=r^{2}[/latex] intersect each other orthogonally at the point [latex]\left ( u,v \right )[/latex]. Then  [latex]u+v=[/latex] _______________.
solution: If two curves cut orthogonally then product of slopes [latex]= -1[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} x^{2}+y^{2} &=1 \\ 2 x+2 y \frac{d y}{d x} &=0 \\ \left(M_{1}\right)_{u, v} &=\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{-x}{y}=\frac{-u}{v} \\ (x-1)^{2}+(y-1)^{2} &=r^{2} \\ \left(M_{2}\right)_{u, v} &=\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)=\left(\frac{-2(x-1)}{2(y-1)}\right)_{(u . v)}=\frac{1-u}{v-1} \\ \because \qquad \qquad M_{1} M_{2} &=-1\\ \frac{-u}{v} \times \frac{1-u}{v-1}&=-1\\ -u+u^{2} &=-v^{2}+v \\ u^{2}+v^{2} &=v+u \\ \because \qquad \qquad x^{2}+y^{2} &=1 \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad u+v &=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 41 Let [latex]f\left ( x \right )[/latex]
 be a real-valued function such that [latex]{f}'\left ( x_{0} \right )=0[/latex]
 for some [latex]x _{0} \in\left ( 0,1 \right )[/latex], and [latex]{f}''\left ( x \right )> 0[/latex]
 for all [latex]x \in \left ( 0,1 \right )[/latex]. Then [latex]f\left ( x \right )[/latex]
 has
solution: [latex]x_{0} \in(0,1)[/latex], where [latex]f(x)=0[/latex] is stationary point and [latex]f^{\prime \prime}(x)>0 \qquad \qquad \forall x \in(0,1)[/latex] So [latex]\qquad \qquad f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=0[/latex] and [latex]\qquad \qquad f^{\prime}(0)>0, \text { where } x_{0} \in(0,1)[/latex] Hence, f(x) has exactly one local minima in [latex](0,1)[/latex]

Question 43 Let p and q be real numbers such that [latex]p^{2}+q^{2}=1[/latex]. The eigenvalues of the matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} p & q\\ q& -p \end{bmatrix}[/latex]
are
solution: Characteristic equation of A [latex] \begin{aligned} \left|A_{2 \times 2}-\lambda I\right|&=(-1)^{2} \lambda^{2}+(-1)^{1} \text{Tr}(A) \lambda+|A|=0 \\ \lambda^{2}-(p-p) \lambda+\left(-p^{2}-q^{2}\right) &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad\lambda^{2}-1 &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad \lambda &=\pm 1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 46 The real numbers, x and y with [latex]y = 3x^2 + 3x + 1[/latex], the maximum and minimum value
of y for [latex]x \in [-2, 0][/latex] are respectively ________
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
y&=3x^{2}+3x+1 \; \;    in \; [-2,0] \\ \frac{\partial y}{\partial x}&=6x+3,\; \; \frac{\partial^2 y}{\partial x^2}=6  \\ \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}&=0\\ 6x+3&=0 \\ x&=\frac{-1}{2} \\ \frac{d^{2} y}{dx^{2}}&=6 \gt 0\text{ minimum} \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum value of y in [-2, 0] is maximum {f(-2), f(0)} max{7, 1} = 7 Minimum value of y in [-2, 0] [latex]min\begin{Bmatrix} f(-2) & f(0) &f(-\frac{1}{2}) \\ \downarrow, &\downarrow, &\downarrow \\ 7& 1 & \frac{1}{4} \end{Bmatrix}+=\frac{1}{4}[/latex] Maximum value 7, minimum value [latex]\frac{1}{4}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 Consider the initial value problem below. The value of y at [latex]x = ln \;2[/latex]. (rounded off to 3
decimal places) is ________ . [latex]\frac{dy}{dx}=2x-y,\; y(0)=1[/latex]
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}&=2x-y \\  y(0)&=1, \; y \text{ at } x=\ln  2\\ \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}+y&=2x \\ P&=1, \;\;     Q=2x \\ I.F.&=e^{\int Pdx}=e^{\int 1dx}=e^{x}\\ \text{Solution, }   Y(I.F)&=\int Q(I.F.)dx\\ye^{x}&=\int 2x\cdot e^{x}dx \\&=2(xe^{x}-e^{x})+C \\ y&=2x-2+ce^{-x} \\ y(0)&=1 \\ 1&=0-2+C \\ C&=3 \\ \therefore \; \; y&=2x-2+3e^{-x} \\ \text{At }x&= \ln 2 \\ y&=2(\ln 2)-2+3e^{-\ln 2} \\ &=1.386-2+\frac{3}{2}\\
&=0.886\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 48 The value of the following complex integral, with C representing the unit circle centered
at origin in the counterclockwise sense, is: [latex]\int_{c}\frac{z^2+1}{z^2-2z}dz[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I&=\int _C \frac{z^2+1}{z^2-2z}dz\;\;\;|z|=1 \\ \text{Using } & \text{Cauchy's integral theorem}\\ \int _C\frac{F(z)}{z-a}dz&=2 \pi i (Re_{(z=a)})\;\;\;...(i)\\ I&=\int _C \frac{z^2+1}{z(z-2)}dz \end{aligned}[/latex] Poles are at z=0 and 2 but only z=0 lies inside the unit circle. Residue at [latex](z=0)=\lim_{z \to 0}\frac{z^2+1}{z(z-2)}[/latex] [latex]Re_{(z=0)}=-\frac{1}{2}[/latex] Using equation (i) [latex]\int _C \frac{z^2+1}{z^2-2z}dz=2 \pi i \times \left ( \frac{-1}{2} \right )=-\pi i[/latex]

question:
Question 49 Which of the following is true for all possible non-zero choices of integers [latex]m, n; m \neq n[/latex],
or all possible non-zero choices of real numbers [latex]p, q ; p\neq q[/latex], as applicable?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \because \; p& \neq q\\ &\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \sin p\theta \cos q\theta d\theta \\ &=\frac{1}{2\pi}\cdot \frac{1}{2}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} [\sin (p+q)\theta + \sin (p-q)\theta] d\theta \\ &=\frac{1}{4\pi}\left [ \frac{-1}{(p+q)}\cos (p+q)\theta -\frac{1}{(p-q)}\cos (p-q)\theta \right ]_{-\pi}^{\pi}\\ &=\frac{-1}{4\pi} \left \{ \frac{1}{(p+q)}(\cos (p+q) \pi -\cos (p+q)(-\pi)) \right.\\ &+\left. \frac{1}{(p-q)}(\cos (p-q) \pi -\cos (p-q)(-\pi)) \right \}\\ &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 50 [latex]ax^3+bx^2+cx+d[/latex] is a polynomial on real [latex]x[/latex] over real coefficients [latex]a, b, c, d[/latex] wherein
[latex]a \neq 0[/latex]. Which of the following statements is true?
solution: Given Polynomial [latex]ax^{3}+bx^{2}+cx+d=0;\; \; \; a\neq 0[/latex] Option (A): If d=0, then the polynomial equation becomes [latex]\begin{aligned} ax^3+bx^2+cx&=0\\ x(ax^2+bx+c)&=0 \\ x=0 \text{ or } ax^2+bx+c&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] d can be choosen to ensure x=0 is a root of given polynomial. Hence, Option (A) is correct. Option B: A third degree polynomial equation with all root equal is given by [latex](x+\alpha )^3=0[/latex] Thus, by selecting suitable values of a, b, c and d we can have all roots identical. Hence, option (B) is incorrect. Option (C): Complex roots always occurs in pairs, So, the given polynomial will have maximum of 2 complex roots and 1 real root. Hence, option (C) is incorrect. Option (D): Nature or roots depends on other coefficients also apart from coefficient 'c'. Hence, option (D) is correct. Hence, the correct options are (A) and (D).

options.A: d can be chosen to ensure that x = 0 is a root for any given set a, b, c.
options.B: No choice of coefficients can make all roots identical.
options.C: a, b, c, d can be chosen to ensure that all roots are complex.
options.D: c alone cannot ensure that all roots are real.

question: Question 51 The probability of a resistor being defective is 0.02. There are 50 such resistors in a circuit. The probability of two or more defective resistors in the circuit (round off to two decimal places)is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} p&=0.02\\ n&=50\\ \lambda &=np=50(0.02)=1\\ p(x\geq 2)&=1-p(x \lt 2)\\ &=1-(p(x=0)+p(x=1))\\ &=1-\left ( \frac{e^{-\lambda }\lambda ^0}{0!}+\frac{e^{-\lambda }\lambda ^1}{1!} \right )\\ &=1-e^{-\lambda }(1+\lambda )\\ &=1-e^{-1}(1+1)=0.26 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 If A=2xi+3yj+4zk and [latex]u=x^2+y^2+z^2[/latex], then div(uA) at (1,1,1) is____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \bigtriangledown \cdot (uA)&=u(\bigtriangledown \cdot A)+(\bigtriangledown A)F\\ &=(x^2+y^2+z^2)[2+3+4]\\ &+(2x\hat{i}+2y\hat{j}+2z\hat{k})(2x\hat{i}+3y\hat{j}+4z\hat{k})\\ &=9(x^2+y^2+z^2)+(4x^2+6y^2+8z^2)\\ At\; (1,1,1)&=9(3)+[4+6+8]\\ &=27+18=45 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 The closed loop line integral [latex]\oint _{|z|=5}\frac{z^3+z^2+8}{z+2}dz[/latex] evaluated counter-clockwise, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \oint _{|z|=5}\frac{z^3+z^2+8}{2+2}dz&=2 \pi j \text{ (sum of residues)} \\ &=2 \pi j \times \left [ \lim_{z \to -2} \frac{(z+2)(z^3+z^2+8)}{(z+2)}\right ] \\ &= 2 \pi j \times \left [ \frac{-8+4+8}{1} \right ]=8 \pi j \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 Consider a 2x2 matrix [latex]M=[v_1\;\; v_2][/latex], where, [latex]v_1\;and \; v_2[/latex] are the column vectors. Suppose [latex]M^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix} u_1^T\\ u_2^T \end{bmatrix}[/latex], where [latex]u_1^T \; and \; u_2^T[/latex] are the row vectors. Consider the following statements: Statement 1: [latex]u_1^T v_1=1\; and \; u_2^Tv_2=1[/latex] Statement 2: [latex]u_1^T v_2=0\; and \; u_2^Tv_1=0[/latex] Which of thefollowing options is correct?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} M^{-1}M &=I \\ \Rightarrow \; \begin{bmatrix} u_1^T\\ u_2^T \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} v_1 & v_2 \end{bmatrix} &= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\\ \begin{bmatrix} u_1^T v_1 & u_1^T v_2\\ u_2^T v_1 & u_2^T v_2 \end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \\ u_1^T v_1=1; &u_1^T v_2 =0\\ u_2^T v_1=1; &u_2^T v_2 =1\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Statement (1) and (2) are both correct. Option (C) is correct.

options.A: Statement 1 is true and statement 2 is false
options.B: Statement 2 is true and statement 1 is false

question: Question 55 The rank of the matrix, [latex]M=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &1 &1 \\ 1& 0& 1\\ 1& 1& 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} M &=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 1\\ 1& 0 & 1\\ 1& 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \\ &R_1\leftrightarrow R_2 \\ &=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1\\ 0& 1 & 1\\ 1& 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \\ &R_3\rightarrow R_3 -R_1 \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1\\ 0& 1 & 1\\ 0& 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix}\\ &R_3\rightarrow R_3-R_2 \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1\\ 0& 1 & 1\\ 0& 0 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}[/latex] Which is in echelon form [latex]\therefore \;\; \rho (A)=3[/latex]

question: Question 56 If [latex]f=2x^3+3y^2+4z[/latex], the value of line integral [latex]\int _c grad \; f\cdot dr[/latex] evaluated over  contour C formed by the segments (-3,-3,2) [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] (2,-3,2) [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] (2,6,2) [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] (2,6,-1) is_______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f&=2x^3+3y^2+4z\\ \Delta f&=6x^2\hat{i}+6y\hat{j}+4\hat{k}\\ \text{curl} (\Delta f)&=\begin{vmatrix} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k}\\ \frac{\partial }{\partial x}&\frac{\partial }{\partial y} &\frac{\partial }{\partial z} \\ 6x^2& 6y & 4\end{vmatrix}\\ \therefore \;\;\int _c\Delta f\cdot dr&=\int _c d(2x^3+3y^2+4z)=0\\ &=\int_{(-3,-3,2)}^{2,-3,2}d(2x^3+3y^2+4z)\\ &+\int_{(2,-3,2)}^{(2,6,2)}d(2x^3+3y^2+4z)\\ &+\int_{(2,6,2)}^{(2,6,-1)}d(2x^3+3y^2+4z)\\ &=70+81+(-12)=139 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 57 The mean-square of a zero-mean random process is [latex]\frac{kT}{C}[/latex], where k is Boltzmann's constant, T is  the  absolute  temperature,  and C is  a  capacitance.  The  standard  deviation  of  the  random process is
solution: Given that, [latex]\begin{aligned} E(x^2)&=\frac{kT}{C}\\ E(x)&=0\\ &=E(x^2)-(E(x))^2\\ Var(x)&=\frac{kT}{C}-0=\frac{kT}{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] Standard deviation [latex]=\sqrt{\frac{kT}{C}}[/latex]

question: Question 58 Which one of the following functions is analytic in the region [latex]|z|\leq 1[/latex]?
solution: By Cauchy integral theorem, [latex]\int \frac{z^2-1}{z+2}dz=0[/latex] Therefore, [latex]\frac{z^2-1}{z+2}[/latex] is analytic in the region [latex]|z|\leq 1[/latex].

question:
Question 61 Let [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0&-1 \\ -1&2 & 0\\ 0& 0 & -2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and [latex]B=A^{3}-A^{2}-4A+5I[/latex], where I is the 3x3 identity matrix. The
determinant of B is ________ (up to 1 decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -1\\ -1 &2 &0 \\ 0 & 0 & -2 \end{bmatrix}\\ |A-\lambda I|=0\\ \begin{bmatrix} 1-\lambda & 0& -1\\ -1& 2-\lambda & 0\\ 0 & 0 &-2-\lambda \end{bmatrix}=0\\ (1-\lambda )((2-\lambda )(-2-\lambda ))-1(0-0)=0\\ \lambda =1,2,-2\\ \text{Eigen value of A are 1,2,-2}\\ \text{Eigen value of } A^3 \text{ are 1,8,-8}\\ \text{Eigen value of } A^2 \text{ are 1,4,4}\\ \text{Eigen value of } 4A \text{ are 4,8,-8}\\ \text{Eigen value of } 5I \text{ are 5,5,5}\\ A^3-A^2-4A+5I \text{ are 1,1,1}\\ \therefore \;\; |B|=(1)(1)(1)=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 Let [latex]f(x)=3x^{3}-7x^{2}+5x+6[/latex]. The maximum value of f(x) over the interval [0, 2] is _______ (up to 1 decimal place).

Question 63 As shown in the figure, C is the arc from the point (3,0) to the point (0,3) on the circle [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}=9[/latex]. The value of the integral [latex]\int_{C}(y^{2}+2yx)dx+(2xy+x^{2})dy[/latex] is _____ (up to 2
decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x^2+y^2&=9\\ x&=3 \cos \theta \\ y&=3 \sin \theta \\ dx&=-3 \sin \theta \; d\theta\\ dy&=3 \cos \theta \;d\theta \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\theta[/latex] varies from 0 to [latex]\frac{\pi}{2}[/latex] [latex] \int (y^2+2xy)dx+(2xy+x^2)dy =\int_{0}^{\pi/2}(9 \sin ^2 \theta +18 \sin \theta \cos \theta )(-3 \sin \theta d\theta )+(18 \sin \theta \cos \theta +9 \cos ^2 \theta )(3 \cos \theta )d\theta [/latex] [latex]=\int_{0}^{\pi/2}(-27\sin ^3 \theta -54 \sin ^2 \theta \cos \theta +54 \sin \theta \cos ^2 \theta +27 \cos ^3 \theta )d\theta =0[/latex]

question: Question 64 If C is a circle |z|=4 and  [latex]f(z)=\frac{z^{2}}{(z^{2}-3z+2)^{2}}[/latex], then [latex]\oint_{C}f(z)dz[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\int \frac{z^2}{(z^2-3z+2)^2}dz\\ &\int \frac{z^2}{(z-1)^2(z-2)^2}dz\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Res. }f(z)_{z=1}&=\lim_{z \to 1}\frac{1}{1!}\frac{d}{dz} \left ((z-1)^2\frac{z^2}{(z-1)^2(z-2)^2} \right )\\ &=\lim_{z \to 1}\left (\frac{2z(z-2)^2-2z^2(z-2)}{((z-2)^4} \right )\\ &=\lim_{z \to 1}\left (\frac{2z(z-2)-2z^2}{((z-2)^3} \right )=\frac{-4}{-1}=4\\ \text{Res. }f(z)_{z=2}&=\lim_{z \to 2}\frac{1}{1!}\frac{d}{dz} \left ((z-2)^2\frac{z^2}{(z-1)^2(z-2)^2} \right )\\ &=\lim_{z \to 2}\left (\frac{(z-1)^2\cdot 2z-z^22(z-1)}{((z-1)^4} \right )\\ &=\lim_{z \to 2}\left (\frac{2z(z-1)-2z^2}{((z-1)^3} \right )=\frac{4-8}{1}=-4\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] By residue theorem, [latex]I=2 \pi i (4-4)=0[/latex]

question: Question 65 Consider a system governed by the following equations [latex]\frac{dx_{1}(t)}{dt}=x_{2}(t)-x_{1}(t)[/latex] [latex] \frac{dx_{2}(t)}{dt}=x_{1}(t)-x_{2}(t)[/latex] The initial conditions are such that [latex]x_{1} \lt x_{2}(0) \lt \infty[/latex]. Let [latex]x_{1f}=\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }x_{1}(t)[/latex] and [latex]x_{2f}=\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }x_{2}(t)[/latex]. Which one of the following is true?

Question 66 Let f be a real-valued function of a real variable defined as f (x)=x-[x], where [x]
denotes the largest integer less than or equal to x. The value of [latex]\int_{0.25}^{1.25}f(x)dx[/latex] is _______ (up to 2 decimal places).
Question 67 Consider a non-singular 2x2 square matrix A. If trace(A)=4 and trace([latex]A^{2}[/latex])=5, the determinant of the matrix A is _________(up to 1 decimal place).
solution: A is 2 x 2 matrix [latex]\begin{aligned} Tr\; A&=4\\ \lambda _1+\lambda _2&=4\\ tr(A^2)&=5\\ \lambda _1^2+\lambda _2^2&=5\\ (\lambda _1+\lambda _2)^2&=\lambda _1^2+\lambda _2^2+2\lambda _1 \lambda _2\\ 2\lambda _1 \lambda _2+5&=16\\ 2\lambda _1 \lambda _2&=11\\ \lambda _1 \lambda _2&=\frac{11}{2}\\ |A|&=\frac{11}{2}=5.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 The value of the integral [latex]\oint_{c} \frac{z+1}{z^{2}-4}dz[/latex] in counter clockwise direction around a circle C of radius 1 with center at the point z=-2 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\int \frac{z+1}{z^2-4}dz\\ &\int \frac{z+1}{(z-2)(z+2)}dz\\ &\int \frac{\frac{z+1}{z-2}}{z+2}dz \;\; \text{where, } f(z)=\frac{z+1}{z-2}\\ &=2 \pi i f(-2)\\ &=2 \pi i \left ( \frac{-2+1}{-2-2} \right )\\ &= 2 \pi i \left ( \frac{-1}{-4} \right )=\frac{\pi i}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 69 The value of the directional derivative of the function [latex]\phi (x,y,z)=xy^{2}+yz^{2}+zx^{2}[/latex] at the
point (2,-1,1) in the direction of the vector [latex]p=i+ 2j + 2k[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \phi &= xy^2+yz^2+zx^2\\ \bigtriangledown \phi &=\bar{i}\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial x}+\bar{j}\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial y} +\bar{k}\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial z} \\ &=\bar{i}(y^2+2xz)+\bar{j}(2xy+z^2)\\&+\bar{k}(2yz+x^2) \\ \bigtriangledown \phi _{(2,-1,1)} &= \bar{i}(1+4)+\bar{j}(-4+1)+\bar{k}(-2+4)\\ &= 5\bar{i}-3\bar{j}+2\bar{k}\\ \bar{P} &= \bar{i}+2\bar{j}+2\bar{k}\\ |\bar{P}|&=\sqrt{1+4+4}=3 \end{aligned}[/latex] THe directional derivative of f(x,y,z) at (2,-1,1) in the direction of [latex]\bar{P}[/latex] is [latex]\bigtriangledown \phi _{at \; P} \cdot \frac{\bar{P}}{|\bar{P}|}= (5\bar{i}-3\bar{j}+2\bar{k})\left ( \frac{\bar{i}+2\bar{j}+2\bar{k}}{3} \right )=\frac{5-6+4}{3}=1[/latex]

question: Question 70 Let f be a real-valued function of a real variable defined as [latex]f(x)=x^{2}[/latex] for [latex]x \gt 0[/latex], and[latex] f(x)=-x^{2}[/latex] for [latex]x \lt 0[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} x^2 & x \geq 0\\ -x^2 & x \lt 0 \end{matrix}\right.\\ f'(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} 2x & x \geq 0\\ -2x & x \lt 0 \end{matrix}\right.\\ f''(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} 2 & x \geq 0\\ -2 & x \lt 0 \end{matrix}\right. \end{aligned}[/latex] The first derivation of f (i.e) f'(x) is not derivable at x=0.

options.B: f(x) is continuous but not differentiable at x=0
options.C: f(x) is differentiable but its first derivative is not continuous at x=0
options.D: f(x) is differentiable but its first derivative is not differentiable at x=0

question: Question 71 The eigen values of the matrix given below are [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1&0 \\ 0& 0 & 1\\ 0 &-3 & -4 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]
solution: The characteristics equation is [latex]|A-\lambda |i=0.[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 0-\lambda & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 0-\lambda & 1\\ 0& -3 &-4-\lambda \end{bmatrix}&=0 \\ -\lambda (4\lambda +\lambda ^2+3)-1(0-0)&=0 \\ -\lambda (\lambda ^2+4\lambda +3)&=0 \\ \lambda =0,(\lambda +1)(\lambda +3)&=0 \\ \lambda &=-1,-3 \\ \lambda &=(0,-1,-3) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 72 A person decides to toss a fair coin repeatedly until he gets a head. He will make at most 3
tosses. Let the random variable Y denote the number of heads. The value of var {Y}, where
var {.} denotes the variance, equals
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E(y)&=0\times \frac{1}{8}+1 \times \frac{7}{8}=\frac{7}{8} \\ E(y^2) &=0^2\left ( \frac{1}{8} \right )+1^2 \times \frac{7}{8}=\frac{7}{8} \\ \text{Variance(y)} &=E(y^2)-(E(y))^2 \\ &= \frac{7}{8}-\frac{49}{64}=\frac{56-49}{64}=\frac{7}{64} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 Let [latex]g(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} -x & x\leq 1\\ x+1, &x\geq 1 \end{matrix}\right. [/latex]  and [latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1-x & x\leq 0\\ x^{2}, & x \gt 0 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Consider the composition of f and g, i.e., [latex](f\circ g)(x)=f(g(x))[/latex]. The number of discontinuities in [latex](f\circ g)(x)[/latex] present in the interval [latex](-\infty ,0)[/latex] is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x)=1-x; &x \lt 0\\ g(x)=-x;&x \lt 0 \end{aligned}[/latex] (Noth are continous for [latex]x \lt 0[/latex]) Therefore, fog(x) is continous for [latex]x \lt 0[/latex] The composite function of two continous function is always continous . Therefore the number of discontinuities are zero.

question: Question 74 The value of the contour integral in the complex-plane [latex]\oint \frac{z^{3}-2z+3}{z-2}dz[/latex] Along the contour |Z|=3, taken counter-clockwise is
solution: Pole, z=2 lies inside |z|=3 [latex]\text{Res }f(z)=\lim_{z \to 2}(z-2)\frac{z^2-2z+3}{z-2}[/latex] [latex]z=2, \;\;\;\;\; =8-4+3=7[/latex] By Cauche redisue theorem, [latex]I=2 \pi i (7)=14 \pi i[/latex]

question: Question 75 Let [latex]y^{2}-2y+1=x[/latex] and [latex]\sqrt{x}+y=5[/latex]. The value of [latex]x+\sqrt{y}[/latex] equals _________. (Give the answer up to three decimal places)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sqrt{x}+y&=5\\ \sqrt{x}+1+5x&=5\\ 2\sqrt{x}&=4\\ x&=4\\ y^2-2y+1&=x\\ (y-1)^2&=x\\ y-1&=\sqrt{x}\\ y&=1+\sqrt{x}\\ y&=1+\sqrt{4}=3\\ \therefore \;\;x+\sqrt{y}&=4+\sqrt{3}=5.732 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 Consider a function f (x, y,z) given by [latex]f(x,y,z)=(x^{2}+y^{2}-2z^{2})(y^{2}+z^{2})[/latex] The partial derivative of this function with respect to x at the point, x = 2, y = 1 and z = 3 is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x,y,z)&=(x^2+y^2-2z^2)(y^2+z^2)\\ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}&=(x^2+y^2-2z^2)(0)+(y^2+z^2)(2x)\\ &=0+(y^2+z^2)(2x)\\ \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \end{matrix}\right|_{x=2,y=1,z=3}&=(1+9)(2)(2)=40 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 Let x and y be integers satisfying the following equations [latex]2x^{2}+y^{2}=34[/latex] [latex]x+2y=11[/latex] The value of (x+y) is ________.

Question 78 Assume that in a traffic junction, the cycle of the traffic signal lights is 2 minutes of green
(vehicle does not stop) and 3 minutes of red (vehicle stops). Consider that the arrival time of
vehicles at the junction is uniformly distributed over 5 minute cycle. The expected waiting time
(in minutes) for the vehicle at the junction is ________.
solution: [latex]t[/latex] be arrival time of vehicles of the junction is uniformaly distributed in [0,5]. Let y be the waiting time of the junction. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Then }y&=\left\{\begin{matrix} 0 &  t \lt 2  \\ 5-t & 2\leq t \lt 5 \end{matrix}\right.\\ y\rightarrow &[0,5]\\ f(y)&=\frac{1}{5-0}=\frac{1}{5}\\ E(y)&=\int_{-\infty }^{0}y(y)dy=\int_{0}^{5}yf(y)dy\\ &=\int_{2}^{5}y\left ( \frac{1}{5} \right )dy=\frac{1}{5}\int_{2}^{5}(5-t)dt\\ &=\frac{1}{5}\left ( 5t-\frac{t^2}{2} \right )|_2^5\\ &=\frac{1}{5}\left [ \left ( 25-\frac{25}{2} \right )-\left ( 10-\frac{4}{2} \right ) \right ]\\ &=\frac{1}{5}\left ( \frac{25}{2}-8 \right )=\frac{1}{5}\frac{9}{2}=0.9 \end{aligned}[/latex]

discarded without noticing its colour. The probability to get a red ball in the second draw is
solution: [latex]P(red)=\frac{5}{10}\frac{4}{9}+\frac{5}{10}\frac{5}{9}=\frac{45}{90}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 80 Consider the line integral [latex]I=\int_{c}(x^{2}+iy^{2})dz[/latex] where [latex]z = x + iy[/latex]. The line C is shown in the figure below. The value of I is
solution: From the diagram C is [latex]y=x[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} I &=\int _C (x^2+iy^2)dz\\ &= \int _C (x^2+iy^2)(dx+idy)\\ &= \int _C(x^2++ix^2)(dx+idy)\\ &= \int _Cx^2 \; dx+ix^2\; dx+ix^2 \; dx-x^2 \; dx\\ &= 2i\int_{0}^{1}x^2 \; dx=\left.\begin{matrix} 2i\left ( \frac{x^3}{3} \right ) \end{matrix}\right|_0^1=\frac{2i}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 81 Only one of the real roots of [latex]f(x)=x^{6}-x-1[/latex] lies in the interval [latex]1\leq x\leq 2[/latex] and bisection method is used to find its value. For achieving an accuracy of 0.001, the required minimum number of iterations is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x)&=x^6-x-1\\ a&=1, b=2, \in =0.01=10^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex] The minimum number of iterations by Bisection method is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{|b-a|}{2^n} &\lt \in\\ \frac{2-1}{2^n} &\lt 10^{-3}\\ \frac{1}{2^n} &\lt \frac{1}{10^{-3}}\\ 2^n &\gt 10^3\\ n &\gt \frac{\ln 1000}{\ln 2}\\ n &\gt 9.96\\ n&=10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 82 A function f(x) is defined as [latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} e^{x}, & x \lt 1\\ lnx+ax^{2}+bx & x\geq 1 \end{matrix}\right. \; where\;  x\in \mathbb{R}[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: [latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} e^x & x \lt 1\\ \ln x+ax^2+bx & x \gt 1 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] At x=1, L.H.S=R.H.S e=a+b    ...(i) At x=1, f'(x) exists [latex]f'(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} e^x & x \lt 1\\ \frac{1}{x}+20x+b & x \gt 1 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] At x=1, L.H.S=R.H.S e=1+2a+b 2a+b=e-1   ...(ii) From equation (i) and (ii), a=-1 b=e+1 f(x) is differentiable at x=1 for unique value of a and b.

options.A: f(x) is NOT differentiable at x=1 for any values of a and b.
options.B: f(x) is differentiable at x = 1 for the unique values of a and b
options.C: f(x) is differentiable at x = 1 for all values of a and b such that a + b = e
options.D: f(x) is differentiable at x = 1 for all values of a and b.

question: Question 83 Consider the differential equation [latex](t^{2}-81)\frac{dy}{dt}+5ty=sin(t)[/latex] with [latex] y(1)=2\pi[/latex]. There exists a unique solution for this differential equation when t belongs to the interval
solution:
The differentail equation, [latex]\begin{aligned}
(t^2-81)\frac{dy}{dt}+5+y&= \sin t\\
\frac{dy}{dt}+\frac{5t}{t^2-81}y&=\frac{\sin t }{t^2-81}\\
P&=\frac{5t}{t^2-81}\\
Q&=\frac{\sin t}{t^2-81}\\
I.F&=e^{\int \rho dt}=e^{\int \frac{5t}{t^2-81}dt}\\
&=e^{\frac{5}{2}\int \frac{2t}{t^2-81}dt}=e^{\frac{5}{2}\ln ({t^2-81})}\\
&=e^{\ln {(t^2-81)^{5/2}}}=(t^2-81)^{5/2}\\
\text{Solution is }&\\
y(t^2-81)^{5/2}&=\int \frac{\sin t}{t^2-81}(t^2-81)^{5/2}dt\\
y&=\frac{\int (\sin t)(t^2-81)^{3/2}dt}{(t^2-81)^{5/2}}+\frac{C}{(t^2-81)^{5/2}}\\
&\text{The solution exist for  } t\neq -9, t\neq +9
\end{aligned}[/latex] Only option (A) not cover 9 and -9. Hence it is correct.

question: Question 84 Let [latex]I=c\int \int_{R}xy^{2}dxdy[/latex], where R is the region shown in the figure and [latex]c=6 \times 10^{-4}[/latex]. The value of I equals________
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
I&=C\int \int xy^2\; dx \; dy\\
&=C\int_{x=1}^{5}\int_{y=0}^{2x}xy^2\; dx \; dy\\
&=C\int_{1}^{5}x\left.\begin{matrix}
\left ( \frac{y^3}{3} \right )
\end{matrix}\right|_{0}^{2x}\; dx\\
&=C\int_{1}^{5}x\frac{8x^3}{3}dx\\
&=C\int_{1}^{5}8\frac{x^4}{3}dx\\
&=C\frac{8}{3}\left.\begin{matrix}
\left ( \frac{x^5}{5} \right )
\end{matrix}\right|_{1}^5\\
&=\frac{8C}{3}\left ( 5^4-\frac{1}{5} \right )\\
&=\frac{8C}{3}(625-0.2)\\
&=\frac{8}{3}(6 \times 10^{-4})(625-0.2)\\
&=0.99968
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 The matrix [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{3}{2} & 0 & \frac{1}{2}\\ 0 & -1 & 0\\ \frac{1}{2}& 0 & \frac{3}{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] has three distinct eigenvalues and one of its eigenvectors is [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] Which one of the following can be another eigenvector of A?
solution: The given matrix is symmetric and all its eigen values are distinct. Hence all its eigen vectors are orthogonal one of the eigen vector is [latex]x_1=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The corresponding orthogonal vector in the given option is C i.e. [latex]x_2=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]{x_1}^T\cdot x_2=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}=1+0-1=0[/latex]

question: Question 86 For a complex number z, [latex]\lim_{z\rightarrow i}\frac{z^{2}+1}{z^{3}+2z-i(z^{2}+2)}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \lim_{z \to i}&=\frac{z^2+1}{z^3+2z-i(z^2+2)}\\ \lim_{z \to i}&=\frac{2z}{3z^2+2-i(2z)}\\ &=\frac{2i}{3i^2+2-i(2i)}\\ &=\frac{2i}{-3+2+2}\\ &=\frac{2i}{-3+4}=2i \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 Let the probability density function of a random variable, X, be given as: [latex]f_X(x)=\frac{3}{2}e^{-3x}u(x)+ae^{4x}u(-x)[/latex] where u(x) is the unit step function. Then the value of 'a' and [latex]Prob\{X\leq 0\}[/latex], respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_x(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} ax^{4x} &x \lt 0 \\ \frac{3}{2}e^{-3x}& x\geq 0 \end{matrix}\right.\\ \int_{-\infty }^{\infty }f_x(x)&=1\\ \int_{-\infty }^{0}ax^{4x}dx+\int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{3}{2}e^{-3x}dx&=1\\ \left [ \frac{ax^{4x}}{4} \right ]_{-\infty }^0+\left [ \frac{\frac{3}{2}e^{-3x}}{-3} \right ]_0^\infty &=1\\ \frac{a}{3}+\frac{3}{6}&=1\\ a&=2\\ P(x\leq 0)&=\int_{-\infty }^{0}2e^{4x}dx \\ &=\left [ \frac{e^{4x}}{2} \right ]_{-\infty }^0=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 88 Let [latex]P=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1\\ 1&3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. Consider the set S of all vectors [latex]\binom{x}{y}[/latex] such that [latex]a^{2}+b^{2}=1[/latex] where [latex]\binom{a}{b} =P\binom{x}{y}[/latex]. Then S is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1\\ 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y \end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix} a\\ b \end{bmatrix} \\ 3x+y &=a \\ x+3y&=b \\ a^2+b^2&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; 10x^2+10y^2+12xy &= 1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Ellipse with major axis along [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex].

options.C: an ellipse with major axis along [latex]\binom{1}{1}[/latex]
options.D: an ellipse with minor axis along [latex]\binom{1}{1}[/latex]

question: Question 89 Let y(x) be the solution of the differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}-4\frac{dy}{dx}+4y=0[/latex] with initial conditions y(0)=0 and [latex]\frac{dy}{dx}|_{x=0}=1[/latex]. Then the value of y(1) is _________.
Question 90 The value of the line integral [latex]\int_{c}(2xy^{2}dx+2x^{2}ydy+dz)[/latex] along a path joining the origin (0,0,0) and the point (1,1,1) is
solution: [latex]\int _C\bar{F}\cdot \bar{dr} [/latex] where, [latex]\bar{F}=xy^2\bar{i}+2x^2y\bar{j}+\bar{k} [/latex] [latex]\bigtriangledown \times \vec{F}=\vec{O} [/latex] [latex](\vec{F}[/latex] is irrotational [latex]\Rightarrow \vec{F}[/latex] is conservative) [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{F}&=\bigtriangledown \phi \\ \phi _x&=2xy^2 \\ \phi _y&=2x^2y \\ \phi _z&= 1\\ \Rightarrow \; \phi &=x^2y^2+z+C \end{aligned}[/latex] where, [latex]\vec{F}[/latex] is conservative [latex]\int _C \bar{F}\bar{dr}=\int_{(0,0,0)}^{(1,1,1)}d\phi =[x^2y^2+z]_{(0,0,0)}^{(1,1,1,)}=2[/latex]

question: Question 91 The solution of the differential equation, for [latex]t \gt 0, y''(t)+2y'(t)+y(t)=0[/latex] with initial conditions y(0) = 0 and y'(0) = 1, is (u(t) denotes the unit step function),
solution: The differentail equation is [latex]y'(t)+2y'(t)+y(t)=0[/latex] So, [latex] (s^2y(s)-sy(0)-y'(0))+2[sy(s)-y(0)]+y(s) =0[/latex] So,  [latex]y(s)=\frac{sy(0)+y'(0)+2y(0)}{s^2+2s+1}[/latex] Given that  [latex] y'(0)=1, y(0)=0 [/latex] So,  [latex]y(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)^2} [/latex] So,  [latex]y(t)=te^{-t}u(t)[/latex]

question: Question 92 A 3 x 3 matrix P is such that, [latex]P^{3} = P[/latex]. Then the eigenvalues of P are
solution: By Calyey Hamilton theorem, [latex]\lambda ^3=\lambda[/latex] [latex]\lambda =0, 1, -1[/latex]

question: Question 93 Consider the function [latex]f(z)=z+z^*[/latex] where z is a complex variable and [latex]z^*[/latex] denotes its complex conjugate. Which one of the following is TRUE?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(z) &=z+z^* \\ f(z)&=2x \text{ is continuous (polynomial)} \\ u &=2x, v=0 \\ u_x &=2, u_y=0 \\ v_x&=0, v_y=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] C.R. equation not satisfied. Therefore, no where analytic.

question: Question 100 The maximum value attained by the function [latex]f(x) = x(x- 1)(x - 2)[/latex] in the interval [1, 2] is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x) &=x^3-3x^2+2x \\ f'(x)&=3x^2-6x+2\\ f'(x)&=0 \;\text{for stationary point} \end{aligned}[/latex] stationary points are [latex]1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[/latex] only [latex]1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[/latex] lies in [1,2] [latex]\begin{aligned} f(1) &=0 \\ f(2)&=0 \\ f\left ( 1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \right )&=-\frac{2}{3\sqrt{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum value is 0.

Question 102 Two coins R and S are tossed. The 4 joint events [latex]H_{R}H_{S},T_{R}T_{S},h_{R}H_{S},T_{R}H_{S}[/latex] have probabilities 0.28, 0.18, 0.30, 0.24, respectively, where H represents head and T represents tail. Which one of the following is TRUE?
solution: From the given information, we can create a joint probability table as follows: From the table, we can get [latex]P(H_R)=0.58, P(T_R)=0.42, P(H_S)=0.52, P(T_S)=0.48[/latex] So, Coins R and S are biased (not fair). So choises (B) and (C) are both false. The coin tosses are not independent since their probability of heads and tails is not 0.5. R and S are dependent. If R and S were independent then all the joint probabilities will be equal to the product of the marginal probabilities. For example [latex]P(H_R\cap H_S)=0.28[/latex] [latex]P(H_R)\cdot P(H_S)=0.58 \times 0.52=0.3016[/latex] Clearly [latex]P(H_R\cap H_S) \neq P(H_R)\cdot P(H_S)[/latex] So R and S are not independent. i.e. R and S are dependent. So, Choise (A) is also false and choise (D) is true.

options.B: R is fair, S is not.
options.C: S is fair, R is not

question: Question 106 Two players, A and B, alternately keep rolling a fair dice. The person to get a six first wins the game. Given that player A starts the game, the probability that A wins the game is
solution: P(A wins) = P( 6 in first throw by A) + P(A not 6, B not 6,)+... [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{6}+\frac{5}{6}\frac{5}{6}\frac{1}{6}+....\\ &=\frac{1}{6}\left ( 1+\left ( \frac{5}{6} \right )^2+\left ( \frac{5}{6} \right )^4+... \right )\\ &=\frac{1}{6}\left ( \frac{1}{1-\left (\frac{5}{6} \right )^2} \right )=\frac{6}{11} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 A solution of the ordinary differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y}{dt^{2}}+5\frac{dy}{dt}+6y=0[/latex] is such that y(0)=2 and [latex]y(1)= -\frac{1-3e}{e^{3}}[/latex]. The value of [latex]\frac{dy}{dt}(0)[/latex] is _______
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
 D^2+5D+6&=0 \\ 
D &=-1,-3 \\ 
 y(t)&=c_1e^{-2t}+c_2e^{-3t} \\ 
\text{Given,  } y(0)&=2 \\ 
\Rightarrow \; c_1+c_2 &=2\;\;...(i) \\ 
 y(1)&=-\left ( \frac{1-3e}{e^3} \right ) \\ 
\Rightarrow \;\; \frac{c_1}{e^2}+\frac{c_2}{e^3} &= -\left ( \frac{1-3e}{e^3} \right ) \\ 
\Rightarrow \;\;ec_1+c_2 &=3e-1\;\;\;...(ii) \\ 
\text{Now solving equation} &\text{ (i) and (ii), we get} \\ 
c_1=3, &c_2=-1\\ 
 \text{Substituting in  }y(t),& we get \\ 
 y(t)&=3e^{-2t}-e^{-3t}\\
\text{Now,   }\frac{dy}{dt}&=-6e^{-2t}+3e^{-3t}\\
\left ( \frac{dy}{dt} \right )_{t=0}&=-6+3=-3 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 The maximum value of "a" such that the matrix [latex]\begin{pmatrix} -3 & 0& -2\\ 1 &-1 & 0\\ 0& a&-2 \end{pmatrix}[/latex] has three linearly independent real eigenvectors is
Question 109 If the sum of the diagonal elements of a 2x2 matrix is -6, then the maximum possible value of determinant of the matrix is ________.
solution: Consider a symmetric matrix [latex]A =\begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ b & d \end{bmatrix}[/latex] Given [latex]a+d=-6[/latex] [latex]|A|=ad-b^2[/latex] Now since [latex]b^2[/latex] is always non-negative, maximum determinant will come when [latex]b^2=0[/latex]. So we need to maximize [latex]\begin{aligned} |A|&=ad-0=ad=a \times -(6+a) \\ &= -a^2-6a\\ \frac{d|A|}{da} &=-2a-6=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; a &=-3 \text{ is the only stationary point} \end{aligned}[/latex] Since, [latex]\left [\frac{d^2|A|}{da} \right ]_{a=-3}=-2 \lt 0[/latex], we have a maximum at [latex]a=-3[/latex]. Since [latex]a+d=-6[/latex], corresponding value of [latex]d=-3[/latex]. [latex]|A|=ad=-3 \times -3=9[/latex]

question: Question 110 If a continuous function f(x) does not have a root in the interval [a,b], then which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: Intermediate value theorem states that if a function is continious and [latex]f(a) \cdot f(b) \lt 0[/latex], then surely there is a root in (a,b). The contrapositive of this theorem is that if a function is continious and has no root in (a,b) then surely [latex]f(a) \cdot f(b) \geq 0[/latex]. But since it is given that there is no root in the closed interval [a,b] it means [latex]f(a) \cdot f(b) \neq 0[/latex]. So surely [latex]f(a) \cdot f(b) \gt 0[/latex] which is choise(C).

question: Question 111 A random variable X has probability density function f(x) as given below: [latex]f(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} a+bx & for \; 0 \lt x \lt 1\\ 0& otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] If the expected value E[X]=2/3, then [latex]Pr[X \lt 0.5][/latex] is _____________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} a+bx & \text{for }0 \lt x \lt 1\\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{matrix}\right.&\\ \text{Now given }E(X)&=2/3\\ \int_{0}^{1}xf(x)dx&=\frac{2}{3}\\ \int_{0}^{1}x(a+bx)dx&=\frac{2}{3}\\ a\left ( \frac{x^2}{2} \right )_0^1+b\left ( \frac{x^3}{3} \right )_0^1&=\frac{2}{3}\\ a\left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )+b\left ( \frac{1}{3} \right )&=\frac{2}{3}\\ 3a+2b&=4\;\;...(i)\\ \text{Now, }\int_{0}^{1}f(x)dx &=1\\ (\text{total probability} & \text{ is always equal to 1})\\ \int_{0}^{1}(a+bx)dx&=\left ( ax+\frac{bx^2}{2} \right )_0^1=1\\ a+\frac{b}{2}&=1\\ 2a+b&=2\;\;...(ii)\\ \text{Now solving } & \text{ (i) and (ii), we get}\\ a&=0,b=2\\ So,\; \;f(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} 2x & \text{for }0 \lt x lt 1\\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{matrix}\right.&\\ \text{Now we need}&\\ P(x \lt 0.5)&=\int_{0}^{0.5}2xdx=2\left ( \frac{x^2}{2} \right )_0^{0.5}\\ &=0.5^2-0^2=0.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 112 The function [latex]f(x)=e^{x}-1[/latex] is to be solved using Newton-Raphson method. If the initial value of [latex]x_0[/latex] is taken as 1.0, then the absolute error observed at [latex]2^{nd}[/latex] iteration is _____.
solution: Given, [latex]f(x)=e^x-1[/latex] or, [latex]f(x_K)=e^{x_K}-1[/latex] and [latex]x_0=1[/latex] In Newton-Raphson method, we have [latex]\begin{aligned} x_{K+1}&=\left [ x_K-\frac{f(x_K)}{f'(x_K)} \right ] \\ x_1&= \left [ x_0- \frac{f(x_0)}{f'(x_0)}\right ]\;\;...(i)\\ \text{Now, } f(x_0)&=e^{x_0}-1=e^1-1=(e-1) \\ \text{and, } f'(x)&=e6x \\ \therefore \;\; f'(x_0) &=e^1=e \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting the values, we get: [latex]\begin{aligned} x_1&=\left [ 1-\frac{e-1}{e} \right ]=\left [ \frac{e-e+1}{e} \right ]=e^{-1}\\ \text{Also, }x_2&=\left [ x_1-\frac{f(x_1)}{f'(x_1)} \right ]\;\;...(ii)\\ \text{Now, }x_1&=\frac{1}{e}=e^{-1} \text{ and } f(x_1)=(e^{e^{-1}}-1)\\ f'(x_1)&=e^{e^{-1}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting the value, we get: [latex]\begin{aligned} x_2&=\left [ e^{-1}-\frac{(e^{e^{-1}}-1)}{e^{e^{-1}}} \right ]\\ &=\left [ e^{-1}-\frac{(e^{0.37}-1)}{e^{0.37}} \right ]=0.06 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 114 Integration of the complex function [latex]f(z)=\frac{z^{2}}{z^{2}-1}[/latex], in the counterclockwise direction, around |z-1|=1, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(z)=\int \frac{z^2}{z^2-1}&=\int f(z) \\ \text{Given circle}& \\ |z-1|&=1 \\ \Rightarrow \; |(x+iy)-1| &=1 \\ (x-1)^2+y^2&=1 \\ x=1, y&= 0, r=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Poles of f(z) [latex]z^2-1=0[/latex] [z=+1, 1] So,  [latex]-1\rightarrow[/latex]Outside circle [latex]\;\; +1\rightarrow[/latex] Inside circle [latex]\begin{aligned} \int \frac{z^2}{(z-1)(z+1)}&=2 \pi i\left [ \frac{z^2}{z+1} \right ]_{z=+1} \\ &= 2 \pi i \left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )=\pi i \\ \text{For pole }(z=-1) &=\int \frac{z^2}{(z-1)(z+1)}=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] as it lies outside from counter.

question: Question 115 Lifetime of an electric bulb is a random variable with density [latex]f(x)=kx^2[/latex], where x is measured in years. If the minimum and maximum lifetimes of bulb are 1 and 2 years respectively, then the value of k is _____
solution: Life time of an electric bulb with density [latex]f(x)=Kx^2[/latex] If minimum and maximum lifetimes of bulb are 1 and 2 years respectively then [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{1}^{2}Kx^2dx &=1\\ \left.\begin{matrix} K\frac{x^3}{3} \end{matrix}\right|_1^2&=1\\ K\left ( \frac{8}{3}-\frac{1}{3} \right )&=1\\ \frac{7K}{3}&=1\\ K&=\frac{3}{7}=0.42 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 116 Let [latex]\triangledown \cdot (f v)=x^2y+y^2z+z^2x[/latex], where f and v are scalar and vector fields respectively.  If [latex]v=yi+zj+xk [/latex], then [latex] v\cdot \triangledown f[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{V}&=y\hat{i}+z\hat{j}+x\hat{k}\\ \hat{i}\frac{\partial (fV)}{\partial x}+\hat{j}\frac{\partial (fV)}{\partial y}+\hat{k}\frac{\partial (fV)}{\partial z}&=x^2y+y^2z+z^2x\\ y\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}+z\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}+x\frac{\partial f}{\partial z}&=x^2y+y^2z+z^2x\;\;...(i)\\ \vec{V}\cdot \Delta f&=y\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}+z\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}+x\frac{\partial f}{\partial z}\;\;...(ii)\\ \text{From equations (i) and (ii)}\\ \vec{V}\cdot \Delta f&=x^2y+y^2z+z^2x \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 118 Two matrices A and B are given below: [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} p &q \\ r& s \end{bmatrix};[/latex]  [latex]B=\begin{bmatrix} p^2+q^2 & pr +qs \\ pr+qs & r^2+s^2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] If the rank of matrix A is N, then the rank of matrix B is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=\begin{bmatrix} p & q\\ r & s \end{bmatrix} \\ A \times A=A^2&=\begin{bmatrix} p^2+q^2 & pr+qs\\ pr+qs & r^2+s^2 \end{bmatrix} =B \\ A^2 &=B \end{aligned}[/latex] Rank of amtrix does not change when we squaring the matrix, hence rank of B = rank of A=N.

Question 121 To evaluate the double integral [latex]\int_{0}^{8}(\int_{y/2}^{(y/2)+1}(\frac{2x-y}{2})dx)dy[/latex], we make the substitution [latex]u=(\frac{2x-y}{2})[/latex] and v=y/2 . The integral will reduce to
solution: [latex]\int_{0}^{8}\left ( \int_{y/2}^{(y/2)+1} \left ( \frac{2x-y}{2} \right )dx\right ) dy[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{2x-y}{2} &=u \\ x-\frac{y}{2}&=u \\ dx&= du\\ \text{at }x &=\frac{y}{2} \\ u&=\frac{\frac{2y}{2}-y}{2}=0 \\ \text{at }x &=\frac{y}{2}+1 \\ u &=\frac{2\left ( \frac{y}{2}+1 \right )-y}{2}\\ &=\frac{y+2-y}{2}=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, integral becomes [latex]\int_{0}^{8}\left (\int_{0}^{1} u du \right )dy[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} v&=\frac{y}{2} \\ dv&=\frac{dy}{2} \\ y=0&= \\ \Rightarrow \;\; v &= 0\\ &y=8 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; v &= 4\\ &\;\;=\int_{0}^{4}\left ( \int_{0}^{1} udu\right )\times 2dv\\ &\;\;= \int_{0}^{4}\left ( \int_{0}^{1} 2udu\right )\times dv \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 122 Consider the differential equation [latex]x^{2}\frac{d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}+x\frac{dy}{dx}-y=0[/latex]. Which of the following is a solution to this differential equation for [latex]x \gt 0[/latex] ?
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
x^2\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}+x\frac{dy}{dx}-y&=0\\
\text{Let,  }x=e^z\leftrightarrow z&=\log x\\
s\frac{d}{dx}=xD=\theta &=\frac{d}{dz}\\
x^2D^2&=\theta (\theta -1)\\
(x^2D^2+xD-1)y&=0\\
[\theta (\theta -1)+\theta -1]y&=0\\
(\theta ^2-\theta +\theta -1)&=0\\
(\theta ^2-1)y&=0\\
\text{Auxiliary equation is }m^2-1&=0\\
m&=\pm 1\\
\text{CF is  }C_1e^{-z}+C_2e^z&\\
\text{Solution is   }y&=C_1e^{-z}+C_2e^z\\
y&=C_1x^{-1}+C_2x\\
y&=C_1\frac{1}{x}+C_2x
\end{aligned}[/latex] One independent solution is [latex]\frac{1}{x}[/latex] Another independent solution is x.

question: Question 125 Consider a dice with the property that the probability of a face with n dots showing up proportional to n. The probability of the face with three dots showing up is____.
solution: Let probability of occurence of one dot is P. So, writing total probability P+2P+3P+4P+5P+6P=1 [latex]P=\frac{1}{21}[/latex] Hence, problem of occurrence of 3 dot is [latex]=3P=\frac{3}{21}=\frac{1}{7}=0.142[/latex]

question:
Question 127 A system matrix is given as follows [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & -1\\ -6& -11&6 \\ -6 & -11 & 5 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The absolute value of the ratio of the maximum eigenvalue to the minimum
eigenvalue is _______.
solution: Characteristic equation [latex]|A-\lambda I|=0[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \begin{vmatrix} -\lambda & 1 & -1\\ -6 & -11-\lambda & 6\\ -6&-11 & 5-\lambda \end{vmatrix} = 0\\ \Rightarrow \; -\lambda [-55+11\lambda -5\lambda +\lambda ^2+66] \\ -1[-30+6\lambda +36]-1[66-66-6\lambda ]=0 \\ \Rightarrow \; -\lambda (\lambda ^2+6\lambda +11)-1(6\lambda +6)+6\lambda =0 \\ \Rightarrow \;-\lambda ^3-6\lambda ^2-11\lambda -6=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\lambda ^3+6\lambda ^2+11\lambda +6=0 \\ \Rightarrow \; (\lambda +1)(\lambda +2)(\lambda +3)=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\lambda =-1,-2,-3 \end{aligned}[/latex] The absolute values of [latex]\lambda[/latex] are [latex]|\lambda |=1,2,3[/latex] Ratio of maximum and minimum eigen value is [latex]=3:1=\frac{3}{1}=3[/latex]

question: Question 128 The line integral of function F=yzi, in the counterclockwise direction, along the circle [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}=1[/latex] at z=1 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \bar{F} &=yz\hat{i} \\ \bigtriangledown \times \bar{F} &=\begin{vmatrix} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k}\\ \frac{\partial }{\partial x} & \frac{\partial }{\partial y} &\frac{\partial }{\partial z} \\ yz& 0 & 0 \end{vmatrix} \\ &= \hat{i}(0)-\hat{j}(0-y)+\hat{k}(0-z)\\ &=0\hat{i}+y\hat{j}-z\hat{k} \end{aligned}[/latex] By strokes theoram, [latex]\begin{aligned} \int _C\bar{F}\cdot d\bar{r}&=\int _S (\bigtriangledown \times \bar{F})\cdot \hat{n}ds\\ &=\int _S (y\hat{j}-z\hat{k})\cdot \hat{k}ds\\ &=\int _S -z \; ds \;\;\;\text{ Since }\; z=1\\ &=\int _S -1 \; ds=(-1)S=(-1)\pi =-\pi \end{aligned}[/latex] where S is surface area of [latex]x^2+y^2=1[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;S=\pi(1)^2=\pi[/latex]

question:

number of heads and tails is (n-3) is
solution: [latex](x+y)^n=\sum_{r=0}^{n} {}^nC_r x^{n-r}y^n[/latex] when, n= probability of occurrence of head y= probability of occurrence of tail Let number of head is P. Number of tail is q P+q=n Total number of tails Given:  |P-q|=n-3 |P-(n-P)|=n-3 n=n-3 which is not posssible. Here required probability is zero.

question: Question 130 Let S be the set of points in the complex plane corresponding to the unit circle. (That is, S={z:|z|=1}). Consider the function f(z)=zz* where z* denotes the complex conjugate of z. The f(z) maps S to which one of the following in the complex plane
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} z&=x+iy\\ z^*&=x-iy\\ zz^*&=(x+iy)(x-iy)\\ &=x^2+y^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] which is equal to (1) always as given [latex]\begin{aligned} |z|&=1\\ zz^*&=x^2+y^2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.B: horizontal axis line segment from origin to (1, 0)

question: Question 131 The solution for the differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}=-9x[/latex] with initial conditions x(0)=1 and [latex]\frac{dx}{dt}|_{t=0}=1[/latex], is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}&=-9x\\ \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}+9x&=0\\ (D^2+9)x &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Auxiliary equation is [latex]m^2+9=0 [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} m&= \pm 3i\\ x&= C_1 \cos 3t+C_2 \sin 3t\;\;...(i)\\ x(0) &=1\;\;i.e.\;x\rightarrow 1\; when t\rightarrow 0 \\ 1&=C_1 \\ \frac{dx}{dt}&=-3C_1 \sin 3t+3C_2 \cos 3t\;\;...(ii) \\ x'(0)&=1\;\; i.e.\;x'\rightarrow 1\; when \; t\rightarrow 0 \\ 1&=3C_2 \\ C_2&=\frac{1}{3}\\ \therefore \;x&=\cos 3t+\frac{1}{3}\sin 3t \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 132 Let [latex]f(x)=xe^{-x}[/latex]. The maximum value of the function in the interval [latex](0,\infty )[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x)&=xe^{-x}\\ f'(x)&=e^{-x}-xe^{-x}=0\\ e^{-x}(1-x)&=0\\ x&=1\\ f''(x)&=-e^{-x}-e^{-x}+xe^{-x}\\ &=e^{-x}(x-2)\\ f''(1)&=e^{-1}(-1)=-e^{-1} \lt 0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence f(x) has maximum value at x=1 [latex]f(1)=1\cdot e^{-1}=e^{-1}[/latex]

question: Question 133 Given a system of equations x + 2y + 2z = [latex]b_1[/latex] 5x + y + 3z = [latex]b_2[/latex] What of the following is true regarding its solutions
